title: Compress the Closed issues panel to a single line when it is not focused
description:
When closed issues is not focused as a panel, it should be compressed down to one line so that we have more space and we're not taking up a bunch of space with closed issues.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] When the Closed panel is NOT focused, it renders as a single line showing only the title and task count (e.g., "Closed (5)")
- [ ] When the Closed panel IS focused, it expands to show the full task list with normal height allocation
- [ ] Pressing `l` to focus the Closed panel expands it; pressing `h` to leave collapses it
- [ ] The compressed Closed panel maintains consistent styling (gray border when unfocused)
- [ ] Height freed by collapsing is redistributed to visible expanded panels (Open and/or In Progress)
- [ ] Compressed panel is still visually clear as a panel (minimal border or separator)
- [ ] No new keybindings required - focus cycling handles expand/collapse automatically

## Implementation Notes

### Files to Modify

1. **`internal/app/panel.go`**
   - Add `collapsed bool` field to `PanelModel` struct (line ~17)
   - Add `SetCollapsed(collapsed bool)` and `IsCollapsed() bool` methods
   - Modify `View()` method to return single-line view when collapsed
   - Create `viewCollapsed() string` helper that renders: `╶─ Closed (N) ─────────────────────╴` or similar

2. **`internal/app/app.go`**
   - Modify `updateSizes()` (lines 343-407):
     - Check if Closed panel is collapsed before allocating height
     - If collapsed, allocate only 1 line to Closed panel
     - Redistribute remaining height to expanded panels
   - Modify `cyclePanelFocus()` (line 491):
     - When focus enters Closed panel: `m.closedPanel.SetCollapsed(false)`
     - When focus leaves Closed panel: `m.closedPanel.SetCollapsed(true)`
     - Call `updateSizes()` after collapse state changes

3. **`internal/app/views.go`**
   - Update `viewMain()` to handle collapsed panel rendering correctly
   - Ensure the collapsed panel still appears in the vertical stack

### Collapsed Panel Visual Design

Option A - Minimal line with box-drawing characters:
```
╶── Closed (5) ──────────────────────────────────────────────╴
```

Option B - Thin bordered strip:
```
├─ Closed (5) ───────────────────────────────────────────────┤
```

Option C - Simple separator style:
```
─── Closed (5) ──────────────────────────────────────────────
```

Recommend Option A for visual consistency with panel borders.

### Height Calculation Logic

```go
// In updateSizes()
closedHeight := 1  // collapsed
if m.closedPanel.IsFocused() {
    closedHeight = panelHeight  // expanded, gets normal allocation
}
// Remaining height distributed to other panels
```

### Edge Cases

- Window resize while Closed is collapsed: maintain collapsed state, recalculate widths
- Filter applied: collapsed panel should show filtered count
- Empty Closed panel: still show collapsed line with "(0)" count
- Very narrow window: ensure collapsed title doesn't wrap or truncate poorly

### Testing Checklist

- [ ] Focus cycling works correctly in all directions
- [ ] Height redistribution looks correct when expanding/collapsing
- [ ] Collapsed count updates when tasks are closed/reopened
- [ ] Filter affects collapsed count correctly
- [ ] Resize handling maintains correct state
- [ ] Works with 0, 1, and many closed tasks
close_reason: Implemented collapsed panel feature: Closed panel now compresses to a single line showing title and count when not focused. Expands when focused via h/l navigation. Height is redistributed to expanded panels.

title: Don't make the search panel a modal, utilize the status bar instead
description:
## Problem

Currently, pressing `/` to search opens a **modal dialog** that overlays the entire screen. This blocks the user from seeing the issue list while typing their search query, which feels disconnected and slower.

The status bar already shows filter results (query text + result counts) after the filter is applied—so the infrastructure for "search in the status bar" partially exists.

## Proposed Solution

Replace the modal-based filter with an **inline search input in the status bar**. Users should be able to:
1. Press `/` and immediately start typing in the status bar
2. See the list filter in real-time as they type
3. Press `Enter` or `Esc` to confirm/exit search mode

This is similar to vim's `/` search behavior or how many TUI apps (lazygit, etc.) handle search.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Pressing `/` activates search mode with cursor in the status bar
- [ ] Status bar displays a text input field (e.g., `/: <user_input>|`)
- [ ] List panels filter in **real-time** as the user types (no Enter required to see results)
- [ ] Result counts update live in the status bar (e.g., `3 results: 1 in progress, 2 open`)
- [ ] `Enter` confirms the filter and returns to normal navigation
- [ ] `Esc` clears the filter and returns to normal navigation
- [ ] Filter persists after exiting search mode (same as current behavior)
- [ ] `Esc` while in normal mode (with active filter) clears the filter
- [ ] Backspace on empty input exits search mode without clearing existing filter
- [ ] Status bar returns to showing keybindings when not in search mode and no filter active

## Implementation Notes

### Files to Modify

1. **`internal/app/app.go`**
   - Remove or repurpose `ViewFilter` mode (may keep for state tracking)
   - Add `searchMode bool` field to track inline search state
   - Modify `distributeTasks()` to be called on every keystroke during search

2. **`internal/app/handlers.go`**
   - Change `/` handler to toggle `searchMode` instead of opening a modal
   - Route text input to `filterQuery` when `searchMode` is true
   - Handle `Enter`, `Esc`, and `Backspace` during search mode

3. **`internal/app/views.go`**
   - Modify `renderStatusBar()` to show an input field when `searchMode` is true
   - Use a `textinput.Model` from Bubble Tea for proper cursor handling
   - Keep the result count display for active filters

4. **`internal/ui/modal.go`** (optional cleanup)
   - Remove `ModalInput` type if no longer needed
   - Or keep for other field editing (title, etc.)

### Key Architectural Changes

- **Remove modal for filter**: No longer use `ui.NewModalInput` for search
- **Add text input to model**: Add a `textinput.Model` field for the search input
- **Real-time filtering**: Call `distributeTasks()` on every character typed
- **Simpler view mode**: May no longer need `ViewFilter` as a distinct view mode

### UX Details

- Cursor should be visible and blinking in the status bar input
- Input should have a prefix like `/: ` to indicate search mode
- Consider showing "No results" feedback when filter matches nothing
- Keep current behavior where pressing `/` again while in search does nothing

### Testing

- Run `lazybeads --check` to verify bd integration still works
- Manual testing: verify search works, filters live, clears properly
- Edge cases: empty search, special characters, rapid typing
close_reason: Implemented inline search in status bar: pressing / now shows search input directly in status bar with real-time filtering as user types, enter to confirm, esc to clear, backspace on empty to exit

title: Add panel titles embedded in borders (lazygit style)
description:
## Overview
Implement panel titles that are embedded/nested within the top border of each panel, similar to how lazygit displays panel titles. The title should appear as part of the border line itself, not inside the panel content.

## Visual Goal
```
╭─ In Progress ─────────────────╮
│ BEADS-001 Fix login bug       │
│ BEADS-003 Add dark mode       │
╰───────────────────────────────╯
```

Instead of:
```
╭───────────────────────────────╮
│ In Progress                   │
│ BEADS-001 Fix login bug       │
│ BEADS-003 Add dark mode       │
╰───────────────────────────────╯
```

## Research Findings

### Lipgloss Native Support (Coming Soon)
There are two open PRs in the lipgloss repository to add this:

1. **PR #384** - `BorderDecoration` API with positioning:
   ```go
   style.BorderDecoration(lipgloss.NewBorderDecoration(
       lipgloss.Top, lipgloss.Center,
       titleStyle.Render("TITLE"),
   ))
   ```

2. **PR #463** - Simpler `BorderTitle(title string)` API

### Current Workaround Options

#### Option A: Manual Border Construction
Build the top border manually by combining border characters with the title:
```go
func renderPanelWithTitle(title, content string, width int, focused bool) string {
    borderStyle := "─"
    corner := "╭"
    rightCorner := "╮"
    
    // Build: ╭─ Title ─────────╮
    titlePart := fmt.Sprintf(" %s ", title)
    remainingWidth := width - len(titlePart) - 2 // -2 for corners
    topBorder := corner + borderStyle + titlePart + strings.Repeat(borderStyle, remainingWidth) + rightCorner
    
    // Render content with side borders only
    // Add bottom border
    // ...
}
```

#### Option B: Custom Border Definition
Create a custom border where the top row includes the title:
```go
func titleBorder(title string, width int) lipgloss.Border {
    topLine := "─ " + title + " " + strings.Repeat("─", width-len(title)-4)
    return lipgloss.Border{
        Top: topLine,
        Bottom: "─",
        Left: "│",
        Right: "│",
        TopLeft: "╭",
        TopRight: "╮",
        BottomLeft: "╰",
        BottomRight: "╯",
    }
}
```

#### Option C: Overlay Approach
Render the panel with border, then overlay the title on the top border using ANSI positioning (more complex, not recommended).

## Implementation Plan

### 1. Check Lipgloss Version
First check if `BorderTitle` or `BorderDecoration` is available in the current lipgloss version. If so, use native support.

### 2. If Not Available - Manual Construction
Create a helper function in `internal/ui/styles.go`:
```go
// RenderPanelWithTitle renders content with a titled border
func RenderPanelWithTitle(title, content string, width, height int, focused bool) string {
    // Select border color based on focus
    borderColor := ColorBorder
    if focused {
        borderColor = ColorPrimary
    }
    
    // Build top border with embedded title
    // Build side borders around content
    // Build bottom border
    // Return composed string
}
```

### 3. Update Panel Rendering
In `internal/app/app.go`, update panel View() methods to use the new helper:
```go
func (p PanelModel) View() string {
    content := p.renderTasks()
    return ui.RenderPanelWithTitle(p.title, content, p.width, p.height, p.focused)
}
```

### 4. Handle Dynamic Width
The title should truncate gracefully if the panel is too narrow:
- Full title if it fits
- Truncated with "..." if too long
- No title if extremely narrow

## Dependencies
- Should be implemented after BEADS-XXX (3-panel refactor) since that establishes the panel structure

## Reference
- [Lipgloss PR #384 - BorderDecoration](https://github.com/charmbracelet/lipgloss/pull/384)
- [Lipgloss PR #463 - BorderTitle](https://github.com/charmbracelet/lipgloss/pull/463)
- lazygit uses configurable border styles following neovim's convention

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Each panel displays its title embedded in the top border
- [ ] Title styling matches lazygit aesthetic
- [ ] Focused panel title is highlighted (different color)
- [ ] Titles truncate gracefully on narrow terminals
- [ ] Works with rounded border style
close_reason: Implemented embedded panel titles in borders (lazygit style)

title: Use terminal text editor for editing task descriptions
description:
## Overview
Rework task editing to use separate keybindings for each field, with modal popups for quick fields and external editor for description.

## Keybindings
| Key | Action | UI |
|-----|--------|-----|
| `t` | Edit title | Modal popup |
| `s` | Edit status | Modal popup with options |
| `p` | Edit priority | Modal popup with P0-P4 |
| `y` | Edit type | Modal popup with options |
| `d` | Edit description | External $EDITOR |

## Modal Popups (lazygit style)

### Title Edit Modal
```
╭─ Edit Title ──────────────────────────╮
│                                       │
│  Fix the authentication bug           │
│                                       │
│  enter: save  esc: cancel             │
╰───────────────────────────────────────╯
```

### Status Select Modal
```
╭─ Status ─────────╮
│ > open           │
│   in_progress    │
│   closed         │
│                  │
│  enter: select   │
╰──────────────────╯
```

### Priority Select Modal
```
╭─ Priority ───────╮
│   P0 (critical)  │
│ > P1 (high)      │
│   P2 (medium)    │
│   P3 (low)       │
│   P4 (backlog)   │
╰──────────────────╯
```

### Type Select Modal
```
╭─ Type ───────────╮
│ > task           │
│   bug            │
│   feature        │
│   epic           │
│   chore          │
╰──────────────────╯
```

## External Editor for Description
- Press `d` to edit description in $EDITOR
- Creates temp file with current description content
- Opens editor (respects $EDITOR, falls back to nano/vi)
- Reads back content on save
- Uses `tea.ExecProcess` to suspend TUI

```go
func (m *Model) editDescription() tea.Cmd {
    if m.selected == nil {
        return nil
    }
    
    editor := os.Getenv("EDITOR")
    if editor == "" {
        editor = "nano"
    }
    
    // Create temp file with .md extension for syntax highlighting
    content := m.selected.Description
    tmpfile, _ := os.CreateTemp("", "lazybeads-*.md")
    tmpfile.WriteString(content)
    tmpfile.Close()
    
    c := exec.Command(editor, tmpfile.Name())
    return tea.ExecProcess(c, func(err error) tea.Msg {
        if err != nil {
            return editorErrorMsg{err}
        }
        newContent, _ := os.ReadFile(tmpfile.Name())
        os.Remove(tmpfile.Name())
        return descriptionEditedMsg{content: string(newContent)}
    })
}
```

## Implementation Steps

### 1. Add Modal Component
Create a reusable modal component in `internal/ui/modal.go`:
- Text input modal (for title)
- Select modal (for status/priority/type)
- Centered overlay on screen
- Keyboard navigation (j/k or arrows)
- Enter to confirm, Esc to cancel

### 2. Add ViewMode States
```go
const (
    ViewList ViewMode = iota
    ViewDetail
    ViewEditTitle    // New
    ViewEditStatus   // New
    ViewEditPriority // New
    ViewEditType     // New
    ViewHelp
    ViewConfirm
)
```

### 3. Update Key Handling
- In list view, add handlers for t/s/p/y/d
- Each opens appropriate modal or launches editor
- Modal handles its own key events

### 4. External Editor Integration
- Use `tea.ExecProcess` for clean terminal handoff
- Handle editor errors gracefully
- Show success/error message after edit

## Benefits
- Quick edits without leaving TUI (status/priority/type)
- Proper markdown editing for descriptions
- Familiar UX (lazygit-like modals)
- Each field has dedicated, memorable keybinding

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `t` opens title edit modal
- [ ] `s` opens status select modal
- [ ] `p` opens priority select modal  
- [ ] `y` opens type select modal
- [ ] `d` opens description in $EDITOR
- [ ] Modals are centered and styled like lazygit
- [ ] j/k navigation in select modals
- [ ] Enter confirms, Esc cancels
- [ ] Changes persist via bd update command
close_reason: Implemented modal-based field editing with keybindings t/s/p/y/d and external editor support for descriptions

title: Navigation in closed panel skips items inconsistently
description:
## Problem
When navigating with j/k in the Closed panel, the cursor skips over items instead of moving one at a time. Navigation is inconsistent and unpredictable.

## Expected Behavior
- j moves down exactly one item
- k moves up exactly one item
- Navigation should be smooth and predictable like in other panels

## Observed Behavior
- Cursor jumps multiple items at once
- Some items are skipped entirely
- Navigation feels "sticky" or erratic

## Possible Causes

### 1. List pagination issue
The closed panel may have many items (13+ in current state). The bubbles/list component might be handling pagination differently when there are more items than visible height.

### 2. Height calculation mismatch
The list's internal height might not match the panel's content height, causing scroll/selection sync issues.

### 3. Cursor position preservation
When tasks are redistributed (on refresh), the cursor position might be getting reset or miscalculated.

## Files to Investigate
- `internal/app/panel.go` - HandleKey() and list setup
- `internal/app/panel.go` - SetSize() list dimensions
- `internal/app/app.go` - distributeTasks() and how selection is preserved

## Debug Steps
1. Add logging to HandleKey() to see actual cursor movements
2. Check if list.Index() matches expected position
3. Verify contentHeight in SetSize matches what View() expects
4. Test with fewer items to see if it's pagination-related

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] j/k moves exactly one item at a time
- [ ] All items in the list are navigable
- [ ] Navigation feels smooth and predictable
- [ ] Works correctly regardless of item count
close_reason: Fixed double-processing of j/k keys - panel Update() was passing keys to list which also handled them

title: The top of the panels is now cut off and not displayed
description:
## Problem

The top of the panels is now cut off and not displayed. After the persistent status bar feature (4f0417e), the panel rendering appears to have a height calculation issue that causes content at the top of panels to be clipped.

## Root Cause Analysis

The issue is likely in the height calculation in `internal/app/app.go` in the `updateSizes()` function:

```go
contentHeight := m.height - 2
```

This calculation reserves 2 lines for the help bar and margins, but may not be correctly accounting for all UI elements, leading to the top of panels being cut off.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All three panels (In Progress, Open, Closed) display their full content including the top border with title
- [ ] The panel title bar (e.g., "╭─ Open (5) ────────╮") is fully visible
- [ ] Content is not clipped at the top or bottom of any panel
- [ ] The status bar at the bottom remains visible and functional
- [ ] The fix works correctly in both wide mode (≥80 cols) and narrow mode (<80 cols)
- [ ] Panel height distribution works correctly when:
  - All 3 panels are visible (In Progress has items)
  - Only 2 panels are visible (In Progress is empty)
- [ ] No regressions in:
  - Panel scrolling behavior
  - Task selection/highlighting
  - Modal overlays

## Implementation Notes

1. **Investigate `updateSizes()` in `internal/app/app.go:343-406`**
   - Check the `contentHeight = m.height - 2` calculation
   - Verify this accounts for all rendered UI elements (error line, status bar, margins)

2. **Check `viewMain()` in `internal/app/views.go:38-93`**
   - The status bar is rendered on line 90 with `ui.HelpBarStyle.Render(statusText)`
   - An error message may also be rendered (lines 82-87) which adds height

3. **Verify panel View() in `internal/app/panel.go:227-333`**
   - The panel border uses "╭─" for top border (line 271) 
   - Confirm the panel's allocated height matches what's rendered

4. **Testing approach**
   - Run `lazybeads` and resize terminal to various sizes
   - Check with different numbers of tasks in each panel
   - Test when In Progress panel is visible vs hidden
   - Use `lazybeads --check` for headless validation
close_reason: Fixed panel top borders being cut off. Two issues: (1) JoinVertical adds newlines between panels, (2) lipgloss borders add 2 lines to Height(). Both now accounted for in height calculations.

title: Refactor to 3 vertically stacked panels (In Progress, Open, Closed)
description:
## Overview
Rework the lazybeads TUI to display 3 vertically stacked panels on the left side (similar to lazygit's layout):
1. **In Progress** panel (top) - Tasks with status `in_progress`
2. **Open** panel (middle) - Tasks with status `open` 
3. **Closed** panel (bottom) - Tasks with status `closed`

## Current Architecture
- **Main file**: `internal/app/app.go` (~989 lines)
- **Styles**: `internal/ui/styles.go`
- **Keys**: `internal/ui/keys.go`
- Uses modal-based navigation with `ViewMode` states (ViewList, ViewDetail, ViewForm, etc.)
- Current h/l keys cycle through filter modes: `FilterOpen → FilterReady → FilterClosed → FilterAll`
- Width-dependent layout: side-by-side panels on wide screens (≥80 chars)

## Required Changes

### 1. Create Panel Component Model
Extract a reusable panel component that can:
- Display a filtered list of tasks
- Track its own selection state
- Handle focus state (focused vs unfocused styling)
- Render with appropriate height allocation

### 2. Update Main Model Structure
```go
type Model struct {
    // Replace single list with 3 panels
    inProgressPanel  PanelModel
    openPanel        PanelModel  
    closedPanel      PanelModel
    focusedPanel     int // 0=inProgress, 1=open, 2=closed
    
    // Keep existing
    detail           viewport.Model
    tasks            []models.Task
    // ...
}
```

### 3. Implement Focus Cycling
- h/l (or ←/→) should cycle focus between the 3 panels
- j/k should navigate within the focused panel
- Enter should show details for selected task in focused panel
- Visual indication of which panel has focus (use `FocusedPanelStyle` vs `PanelStyle`)

### 4. Update Layout Logic
- Divide available height into 3 sections (can be equal thirds or proportional)
- Stack panels vertically using `lipgloss.JoinVertical`
- Detail panel remains on the right side (when in wide mode)

### 5. Update View Rendering
```go
func (m Model) viewMain() string {
    // Stack 3 panels vertically
    leftColumn := lipgloss.JoinVertical(lipgloss.Left,
        m.inProgressPanel.View(),
        m.openPanel.View(),
        m.closedPanel.View(),
    )
    
    // Join with detail panel if in wide mode
    if m.width >= 80 {
        return lipgloss.JoinHorizontal(lipgloss.Top,
            leftColumn,
            m.viewDetail(),
        )
    }
    return leftColumn
}
```

### 6. Update Task Distribution
When tasks load or refresh, distribute them to the appropriate panels:
```go
func (m *Model) distributeTasks() {
    var inProgress, open, closed []models.Task
    for _, t := range m.tasks {
        switch t.Status {
        case "in_progress":
            inProgress = append(inProgress, t)
        case "open":
            open = append(open, t)
        case "closed":
            closed = append(closed, t)
        }
    }
    m.inProgressPanel.SetTasks(inProgress)
    m.openPanel.SetTasks(open)
    m.closedPanel.SetTasks(closed)
}
```

## Key Files to Modify
- `internal/app/app.go` - Main refactor target
- `internal/ui/styles.go` - Add multi-panel layout styles
- `internal/ui/keys.go` - Update keybindings for panel focus

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] 3 panels stack vertically on the left
- [ ] Each panel shows tasks filtered by status
- [ ] h/l cycles focus between panels (visual feedback)
- [ ] j/k navigates within focused panel
- [ ] Enter shows details for selected task
- [ ] Detail panel shows on right side in wide mode
- [ ] All existing actions (add, edit, close, delete) work on focused panel's selection

title: Add LazyGit-style custom commands system
description:
## Overview

Add a user-configurable custom commands system similar to LazyGit, allowing users to define shell commands that can be triggered by keybindings from within the TUI.

## Motivation

When working with beads in a tmux environment, users often want to:
- Shell out to Claude to AI-enhance issue descriptions
- Open files in an existing nvim pane
- Run custom scripts with issue context
- Integrate with other tools in their workflow

A generic custom commands system enables all these workflows without hardcoding specific integrations.

## Proposed Config Format

Location: `~/.config/lazybeads/config.yml`

```yaml
customCommands:
  - key: "D"
    description: "AI flesh out description"
    context: "list"  # list, detail, or global
    command: >-
      tmux split-window -v "claude --print 'Act as a PM. Flesh out this issue. Title: {{.Title}} Description: {{.Description}}' | less"
    
  - key: "C"
    description: "Claude agent on issue"
    context: "list"
    command: >-
      tmux split-window -h "claude 'Work on beads issue {{.ID}}: {{.Title}}'"

  - key: "E"
    description: "Edit in nvim pane"
    context: "detail"
    command: >-
      nvim_pane=$(tmux list-panes -F '#{pane_id}:#{pane_current_command}' | grep -iE ':n?vim' | head -1 | cut -d: -f1);
      if [ -n "$nvim_pane" ]; then
        tmux send-keys -t "$nvim_pane" Escape ":e {{.FilePath}}" Enter;
        tmux select-pane -t "$nvim_pane";
      else
        tmux split-window -v "nvim '{{.FilePath}}'";
      fi
```

## Template Variables

Available from the selected Task model:

| Variable | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `{{.ID}}` | string | Issue ID (e.g., `lazybeads-abc`) |
| `{{.Title}}` | string | Issue title |
| `{{.Description}}` | string | Full description text |
| `{{.Status}}` | string | Status: open, in_progress, closed |
| `{{.Priority}}` | int | Priority 0-4 |
| `{{.Type}}` | string | Type: task, bug, feature, epic, chore |
| `{{.Assignee}}` | string | Assigned user |
| `{{.FilePath}}` | string | Path to .beads/issues/<id>.md file |

## Implementation Plan

### 1. Config package (`internal/config/`)

```go
type Config struct {
    CustomCommands []CustomCommand `yaml:"customCommands"`
}

type CustomCommand struct {
    Key         string `yaml:"key"`
    Description string `yaml:"description"`
    Context     string `yaml:"context"` // list, detail, global
    Command     string `yaml:"command"`
}

func Load() (*Config, error)
```

- Load from `~/.config/lazybeads/config.yml`
- Fall back to empty config if file doesnt exist
- Use `gopkg.in/yaml.v3` for parsing

### 2. Dynamic keybinding registration

In `internal/ui/keys.go`:
- Add `CustomCommands []key.Binding` slice to KeyMap
- Populate from config at startup
- Include in help display

### 3. Command execution

In `internal/app/handlers.go`:
- Add handler for custom command keys in `handleListKeys()` and `handleDetailKeys()`
- Use Go `text/template` to render command with Task data
- Execute via `exec.Command("sh", "-c", renderedCommand).Start()` (non-blocking for tmux)
- No need for `tea.ExecProcess` since tmux commands return immediately

### 4. Help integration

- Show custom commands in help view with their descriptions
- Group separately from built-in commands

## Key Files to Modify

- `internal/config/config.go` (new)
- `internal/ui/keys.go` - add CustomCommands slice
- `internal/app/app.go` - load config, pass to Model
- `internal/app/handlers.go` - handle custom command execution
- `internal/app/views.go` - show custom commands in help
- `go.mod` - add yaml dependency

## Testing

- Config parsing with various YAML formats
- Template rendering with special characters
- Command execution (mock exec)
- Help display with custom commands

## Reference

LazyGit custom commands: https://github.com/jesseduffield/lazygit/blob/master/docs/Custom_Command_Keybindings.md

User's lazygit config pattern (for tmux/nvim integration):
```yaml
os:
  edit: >-
    nvim_pane=$(tmux list-panes -F '#{pane_id}:#{pane_current_command}' | grep -iE ':n?vim' | head -1 | cut -d: -f1);
    if [ -n "$nvim_pane" ]; then
      tmux send-keys -t "$nvim_pane" Escape ":e {{filename}}" Enter;
      tmux select-pane -t "$nvim_pane";
    else
      tmux split-window -v "nvim '{{filename}}'";
    fi
```
close_reason: Implemented LazyGit-style custom commands: config package for ~/.config/lazybeads/config.yml, template-based command rendering with task data, non-blocking execution for tmux integration, help view integration

title: Conditionally show In Progress panel only when tasks exist
description:
## Overview
The In Progress panel should only be visible when there are tasks with `in_progress` status. When hidden, the remaining panels (Open and Closed) should stretch to fill the available height.

## Current Behavior
- In Progress panel always shows, even when empty ("no tasks")
- Takes up 1/3 of vertical space regardless of content

## Desired Behavior
- Hide In Progress panel entirely when no in_progress tasks
- Remaining panels expand to fill the space:
  - 2 panels: each gets 1/2 height
  - 3 panels: each gets 1/3 height (current behavior when all shown)

## Implementation

### Dynamic Panel Visibility
```go
func (m *Model) getVisiblePanels() []PanelType {
    var panels []PanelType
    if len(m.inProgressTasks) > 0 {
        panels = append(panels, PanelInProgress)
    }
    panels = append(panels, PanelOpen)
    // Blocked panel (from lazybeads-ej4) would go here
    panels = append(panels, PanelClosed)
    return panels
}
```

### Dynamic Height Distribution
```go
func (m *Model) updateSizes() {
    visiblePanels := m.getVisiblePanels()
    numPanels := len(visiblePanels)
    
    panelHeight := contentHeight / numPanels
    remainder := contentHeight % numPanels
    
    // Distribute heights to visible panels only
    for i, panel := range visiblePanels {
        h := panelHeight
        if i < remainder {
            h++
        }
        m.setPanelSize(panel, panelWidth, h)
    }
}
```

### Focus Management
- If In Progress panel disappears while focused, move focus to Open panel
- When cycling focus with h/l, skip hidden panels
- Update `cyclePanelFocus()` to only cycle through visible panels

### View Rendering
```go
func (m Model) viewMain() string {
    var panels []string
    if m.inProgressPanel.TaskCount() > 0 {
        panels = append(panels, m.inProgressPanel.View())
    }
    panels = append(panels, m.openPanel.View())
    panels = append(panels, m.closedPanel.View())
    
    leftColumn := lipgloss.JoinVertical(lipgloss.Left, panels...)
    // ...
}
```

## Related Issues
- lazybeads-ej4: Similar pattern for Blocked panel (conditional visibility)
- Should coordinate implementation to share the dynamic panel logic

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] In Progress panel hidden when no in_progress tasks
- [ ] Open and Closed panels expand to fill space (50/50)
- [ ] Focus moves gracefully when panel appears/disappears
- [ ] h/l cycling skips hidden panels
- [ ] Panel reappears when a task moves to in_progress
close_reason: Implemented dynamic panel visibility. In Progress panel now only shows when there are in_progress tasks. Open/Closed panels expand to fill available space (50/50). Focus management handles panel appearance/disappearance gracefully.

title: Make the keyboard shortcuts pane scrollable
description:
## Problem
The keyboard shortcuts help pane (`?` view) displays static content that may overflow the terminal height, especially when custom commands are configured. Currently, users cannot scroll to see all shortcuts if they exceed the visible area.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] The help view supports vertical scrolling with j/k (or up/down arrow keys)
- [ ] The help view supports page up/down (Ctrl+U/Ctrl+D)
- [ ] The scroll position is visually indicated (e.g., percentage, scroll bar, or "more below" indicator)
- [ ] The help bar at the bottom shows available scroll keys (j/k or arrows)
- [ ] Pressing `?` or `esc` closes the help view and returns to list view
- [ ] Scroll state resets when reopening the help view

## Implementation Notes

### Current State
- Help view is rendered in `viewHelp()` in `internal/app/views.go:113-168`
- Content is static text built in a string, rendered with `ui.OverlayStyle`
- No scrolling mechanism exists - content is rendered directly

### Recommended Approach
1. Add a `viewport.Model` for the help pane (similar to the detail panel)
2. Initialize it in `New()` in `internal/app/app.go`
3. Set content in `viewHelp()` instead of rendering directly
4. Handle j/k/Ctrl+U/Ctrl+D keys in `handleKeyPress()` when `m.mode == ViewHelp`
5. Update sizes in `updateSizes()` to set help viewport dimensions

### Key Files to Modify
- `internal/app/app.go` - Add `helpViewport viewport.Model` to Model struct
- `internal/app/views.go` - Update `viewHelp()` to use viewport
- `internal/app/handlers.go` - Add scroll key handling for ViewHelp mode

### Testing
- Run `lazybeads` and press `?` to open help
- Resize terminal to be smaller than help content height
- Verify j/k scrolls up/down
- Verify Ctrl+U/Ctrl+D pages up/down
- Verify escape/? closes help view

title: Add conditional Blocked panel and compact Closed panel (stash-style)
description:
## Overview
Two enhancements to the panel layout:

1. **Blocked Panel** - A conditional panel that only appears when there are blocked issues, positioned below Open/Ready tasks
2. **Compact Closed Panel** - Instead of listing all closed issues, show a compacted single-line summary (like lazygit's stash panel)

## Visual Goal

### When blocked issues exist:
```
╭─ In Progress (2) ─────────────╮
│ BEADS-001 Fix login bug       │
│ BEADS-003 Add dark mode       │
╰───────────────────────────────╯
╭─ Open (5) ────────────────────╮
│ BEADS-004 Add user settings   │
│ BEADS-007 Update docs         │
╰───────────────────────────────╯
╭─ Blocked (1) ─────────────────╮
│ BEADS-002 Deploy to prod      │
╰───────────────────────────────╯
╭─ Closed ──────────────────────╮
│   12 closed issues            │
╰───────────────────────────────╯
```

### When no blocked issues:
```
╭─ In Progress (2) ─────────────╮
│ ...                           │
╰───────────────────────────────╯
╭─ Open (5) ────────────────────╮
│ ...                           │
╰───────────────────────────────╯
╭─ Closed ──────────────────────╮
│   12 closed issues            │
╰───────────────────────────────╯
```

## Blocked Panel Details

### Conditional Rendering
- Only render the Blocked panel if `len(blockedTasks) > 0`
- When it appears, it should be focusable like other panels
- When it disappears (last blocked issue resolved), focus should move to adjacent panel

### Data Source
Use `bd blocked` or filter tasks where `blocked_by` is not empty:
```go
func (m *Model) getBlockedTasks() []models.Task {
    var blocked []models.Task
    for _, t := range m.tasks {
        if len(t.BlockedBy) > 0 && t.Status != "closed" {
            blocked = append(blocked, t)
        }
    }
    return blocked
}
```

### Focus Management
```go
type PanelType int
const (
    PanelInProgress PanelType = iota
    PanelOpen
    PanelBlocked  // Only in focus rotation when visible
    PanelClosed
)

func (m *Model) getVisiblePanels() []PanelType {
    panels := []PanelType{PanelInProgress, PanelOpen}
    if len(m.blockedTasks) > 0 {
        panels = append(panels, PanelBlocked)
    }
    panels = append(panels, PanelClosed)
    return panels
}
```

## Compact Closed Panel Details

### Stash-Style Display
Like lazygit's stash panel, show a minimal summary instead of listing items:
- Single line showing count: `12 closed issues`
- Or if empty: `No closed issues`
- Optionally show recent closure: `12 closed (latest: 2h ago)`

### Expandable Behavior (Optional Enhancement)
Could support Enter to expand into full list view:
- Default: Compact single-line summary
- Press Enter on Closed panel: Expand to show list of closed issues
- Press Esc or Enter again: Collapse back to summary

### Implementation
```go
type ClosedPanelModel struct {
    count    int
    expanded bool
    tasks    []models.Task
    // ...
}

func (p ClosedPanelModel) View() string {
    if p.expanded {
        // Render full list like other panels
        return p.renderTaskList()
    }
    // Render compact summary
    summary := fmt.Sprintf("  %d closed issues", p.count)
    return ui.RenderPanelWithTitle("Closed", summary, p.width, 3, p.focused)
}
```

### Height Allocation
- Compact closed panel should take minimal height (3 lines: top border, content, bottom border)
- More vertical space available for active panels (In Progress, Open, Blocked)

## Dynamic Height Distribution
With conditional panels and compact closed, height allocation becomes dynamic:

```go
func (m *Model) calculatePanelHeights() {
    available := m.height - 4 // margins
    closedHeight := 3         // Fixed minimal height for compact
    
    visibleActivePanels := 2  // In Progress + Open
    if len(m.blockedTasks) > 0 {
        visibleActivePanels++
    }
    
    activeHeight := (available - closedHeight) / visibleActivePanels
    
    m.inProgressPanel.SetHeight(activeHeight)
    m.openPanel.SetHeight(activeHeight)
    if len(m.blockedTasks) > 0 {
        m.blockedPanel.SetHeight(activeHeight)
    }
    m.closedPanel.SetHeight(closedHeight)
}
```

## Panel Order (Top to Bottom)
1. In Progress - Active work
2. Open/Ready - Available work  
3. Blocked (conditional) - Work waiting on dependencies
4. Closed (compact) - Completed work summary

## Dependencies
- Depends on lazybeads-9as (3-panel refactor) - need basic panel structure first

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Blocked panel only appears when blocked issues exist
- [ ] Blocked panel positioned between Open and Closed
- [ ] Focus cycling skips Blocked panel when not visible
- [ ] Focus moves gracefully when Blocked panel appears/disappears
- [ ] Closed panel shows compact summary (count only)
- [ ] Closed panel takes minimal height (3 lines)
- [ ] Active panels get more vertical space
- [ ] (Optional) Closed panel can expand to show full list

title: Add CLI flag to show config loading status
description:
## Overview

Add a CLI flag or subcommand (e.g., `lazybeads --config` or `lazybeads config`) that displays config loading diagnostics for debugging purposes.

## Motivation

When setting up custom commands via `LAZYBEADS_CONFIG` or the default config path, users need a way to verify:
- Whether a config file was found and loaded
- Which path the config is being loaded from
- Whether the config parsed successfully
- What custom commands were registered

This helps debug issues like typos in `LAZYBEADS_CONFIG`, malformed YAML, or confusion about which config file is active.

## Proposed Output

```
$ lazybeads --config

Config Status
  LAZYBEADS_CONFIG: /Users/jeremy/.dotfiles/lazybeads.yml
  Config path:      /Users/jeremy/.dotfiles/lazybeads.yml
  File exists:      yes
  Parse status:     ok

Custom Commands (6 loaded)
  D  "AI flesh out description"     (list)
  C  "Claude agent on issue"        (list)
  R  "AI review issue"              (detail)
  E  "Edit in nvim pane"            (detail)
  W  "Start work (claim + in_progress)" (list)
  X  "Close issue"                  (list)
```

If config is missing or invalid:
```
$ lazybeads --config

Config Status
  LAZYBEADS_CONFIG: (not set)
  Config path:      /Users/jeremy/.config/lazybeads/config.yml
  File exists:      no
  Parse status:     n/a (no config file)

Custom Commands (0 loaded)
  (none)
```

## Implementation Notes

- Add `--config` flag to `main.go` 
- Show `LAZYBEADS_CONFIG` env var value (or "not set")
- Show resolved `ConfigPath()` 
- Check if file exists with `os.Stat`
- Attempt to parse and report any YAML errors
- List loaded custom commands with key, description, context
- Exit after printing (don't launch TUI)

## Key Files
- `main.go` - add flag handling
- `internal/config/config.go` - may need helper to return parse errors separately

title: Add configurable color theming via config.yml
description:
## Summary

Allow users to customize the color theme of LazyBeads through the config file (`~/.config/lazybeads/config.yml`). Currently all colors are hardcoded in `internal/ui/styles.go`. This feature will enable personalization and better accessibility for users with different color preferences or vision needs.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Users can define a `theme` section in `config.yml` to override default colors
- [ ] All base colors (primary, secondary, accent, warning, danger, muted, white, magenta, border) are configurable
- [ ] Priority colors (P0-P4) can be customized
- [ ] Status colors (open, in_progress, closed) can be customized
- [ ] Invalid color values are handled gracefully with fallback to defaults
- [ ] Missing theme config uses existing defaults (backward compatible)
- [ ] Color values support both ANSI color numbers (0-255) and hex codes (#RRGGBB)

## Example Config

```yaml
theme:
  colors:
    primary: "#00ff00"     # or "2" for ANSI green
    secondary: "#0000ff"
    accent: "#00ffff"
    warning: "#ffff00"
    danger: "#ff0000"
    muted: "8"
    border: "8"
  
  priority:
    p0: "#ff0000"          # Critical
    p1: "#ffaa00"          # High
    p2: "#0066ff"          # Medium
    p3: "8"                # Low
    p4: "8"                # Backlog
  
  status:
    open: "#00ff00"
    in_progress: "#ffff00"
    closed: "8"
```

## Implementation Notes

### Files to Modify

1. **`internal/config/config.go`**
   - Add `Theme` struct to `Config`
   - Add `ThemeColors`, `PriorityColors`, `StatusColors` sub-structs
   - Colors should be `*string` (pointers) to distinguish unset from empty

2. **`internal/ui/styles.go`**
   - Add `InitTheme(cfg *config.Config)` function
   - Replace hardcoded color vars with theme-aware initialization
   - Keep existing defaults as fallbacks
   - Add helper to parse color string (ANSI number or hex) into `lipgloss.Color`

3. **`main.go`**
   - Call `ui.InitTheme(cfg)` after loading config

### Color Parsing

```go
func parseColor(s string, fallback lipgloss.Color) lipgloss.Color {
    if s == "" {
        return fallback
    }
    // lipgloss.Color accepts both ANSI numbers and hex codes
    return lipgloss.Color(s)
}
```

### Considerations

- Keep the current lazygit-inspired theme as the default
- Validate that styles using colors are re-initialized after theme load
- Consider adding `--config` flag diagnostic output for theme loading
- Future: Could support named themes (e.g., `theme: catppuccin`)

title: Fix panel borders and equal height distribution
description:
## Problem
Three visual issues with the current panel layout:

### 1. Border Characters Are Inconsistent
The panel title borders appear broken/mixed. From the screenshot:
```
─ In Progress (0) ─══════
```
Should be consistent rounded borders like:
```
╭─ In Progress (0) ────────╮
```

Likely causes:
- Mixing different border character sets (single `─` vs double `═`)
- Title insertion not properly using the same border character
- Possible encoding/rendering issue with border construction

### 2. Panels Don't Fill Available Height
- Large empty space below the Closed panel
- All 3 panels should stretch to fill the full available height equally
- Current behavior: panels only take the height of their content + minimal padding

### 3. Long Titles Stretch Panels Instead of Truncating
- Long issue titles cause the panel width to expand beyond the expected fixed width
- Titles should truncate with "..." when they exceed the available width
- Panel width should remain fixed regardless of content length

Example from screenshot:
```
○ P1 Add conditional Blocked panel and compact Closed panel (stash-style)
```
This pushes the panel wider. Should truncate like:
```
○ P1 Add conditional Blocked panel and com...
```

## Expected Behavior
- Panels should divide available vertical space equally (height / 3 for each)
- Border characters should be consistent (all rounded: `╭`, `─`, `╮`, `│`, `╰`, `╯`)
- Title should be embedded cleanly in the top border
- Panel width should be fixed (e.g., 50% of terminal width in wide mode)
- Long issue titles should truncate with "..."

## Visual Goal
```
╭─ In Progress (0) ─────────────────────╮
│ (no tasks)                            │
│                                       │
│                                       │
│                                       │
╰───────────────────────────────────────╯
╭─ Open (2) ────────────────────────────╮
│ ○ P1 Fix panel borders and equal h... │
│ ○ P1 Add conditional Blocked panel... │
│                                       │
│                                       │
╰───────────────────────────────────────╯
╭─ Closed (13) ─────────────────────────╮
│ ● P2 Filter bar: fuzzy search...      │
│ ● P2 Task form: create and edit...    │
│ ...                                   │
╰───────────────────────────────────────╯
```

## Files to Check
- `internal/app/app.go` - Panel height/width calculation and layout
- `internal/ui/styles.go` - Border styling, title rendering, text truncation

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All border characters are consistent (rounded style)
- [ ] Title embedded cleanly in top border with `─` characters
- [ ] Panels divide available height equally
- [ ] No empty space below the bottom panel
- [ ] Panel width is fixed, not content-dependent
- [ ] Long issue titles truncate with "..."
- [ ] Works at various terminal sizes
close_reason: Fixed panel borders, height distribution, and title truncation
